Melanocytic nevi (nv): Regularly examine your skin for any changes in moles or new growths.
Protect your skin from the sun by wearing sunscreen with a high SPF and seeking shade during peak sun hours.
Schedule regular skin screenings with a dermatologist to monitor for any signs of melanocytic nevi (nv).
Melanoma (mel): Be vigilant about changes in existing moles or the appearance of new moles.
Seek immediate medical attention if you notice any suspicious changes in your skin, such as asymmetry, irregular borders, uneven color, or changes in size or shape.
Benign keratosis-like lesions (bkl): Moisturize your skin regularly to keep it hydrated and prevent dryness.
Avoid picking or scratching at benign keratosis-like lesions (bkl) to prevent irritation or infection.
Consult with a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and management of benign keratosis-like lesions.
Basal cell carcinoma (bcc): Protect your skin from the sun to reduce the risk of basal cell carcinoma (bcc) by wearing protective clothing, seeking shade, and using sunscreen with a high SPF.
Avoid tanning beds and excessive sun exposure to minimize the risk of developing basal cell carcinoma.
Schedule regular skin checks with a dermatologist for early detection and treatment of any suspicious lesions.
Actinic keratoses (akiec): Protect your skin from the sun to prevent actinic keratoses (akiec) by wearing sunscreen, protective clothing, and seeking shade.
Avoid prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation, including tanning beds and sunlamps.
Consult with a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment of actinic keratoses.
Vascular lesions (vasc): Manage underlying health conditions that may contribute to vascular lesions (vasc), such as high blood pressure or diabetes.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet to support overall skin health.
Consult with a dermatologist for evaluation and treatment options for vascular lesions.
Dermatofibroma (df): Protect your skin from irritation or injury to reduce the risk of developing dermatofibromas (df).
Avoid picking or scratching at skin lesions, and handle skin gently during skincare routines.
Consult with a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and management of dermatofibromas.
